properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme wind chill values of -45 to -50 are expected to occur overnight and into the morning hours for portions of northern Manitoba. These wind chill values will moderate throughout the day on Tuesday. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Sant√© at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A total of 15 to 20 cm of snow will fall by Tuesday morning as a warm front moves across the area. For the Prince George region, area highways will likely see more snow than the city so travellers are advised to exercise caution. Heavy snow will end this evening in Quesnel and near midnight for Prince George, McGregor and Fort St. James. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:

Remarks: Snow combined with strong northwesterly winds, will result in poor visibility in blowing snow this evening. Conditions will improve overnight tonight as winds ease and the snow tapers off. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall still possible for southwestern Nova Scotia on Tuesday night and Wednesday, less likely elsewhere. Total snowfall: possibly reaching 10 cm in the southwest, with only 2 to 5 cm now expected from Halifax eastward Locations: Atlantic coastal regions of Nova Scotia. Time span: Tuesday evening until noon Wednesday for Yarmouth County to Halifax Metro and Halifax County West. Wednesday morning to Wednesday evening for Halifax County - East of Porters Lake to Sydney Metro and Cape Breton County. Remarks: An approaching low pressure system is now expected to track further south of Nova Scotia than previously forecast on Tuesday night and Wednesday. Snow is still forecast to begin over southwestern Nova Scotia Tuesday afternoon and then spread eastward, reaching Cape Breton on Wednesday morning. However, total snowfall is now only expected to approach 10 cm over the South Shore from Yarmouth to Lunenburg Counties. Due to the uncertainty which remains in the forecast track, the snowfall forecast may be revised as the system approaches. In any case, this snowfall event has the potential to create difficult driving conditions in some areas during the Wednesday morning commute. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T12:00:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-16T20:01:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2741419381.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Large waves, pounding surf and elevated sea water levels are expected. Wave heights: 5 to 8 metres, breaking upon approach to shore. Locations: west-facing shorelines from Hawkes Bay to Port aux Basques. Time span: until early Tuesday morning. Next high tide: 1:30A.M. to 3:30A.M. Tuesday morning. Remarks: Storm surge and minor coastal flooding is possible along shorelines exposed to the west, especially near high tide tonight. Although tonight's high tide is not expected to be as high as the tide earlier this afternoon, the stronger winds and higher waves are expected to have similar impacts as experienced today. Water levels will begin to subside Tuesday morning as the tide drops. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Additional snowfall: locally up to 5 cm in snow squalls. Maximum wind gusts: westerly 80 km/h except up 100 km/h along the coast until Tuesday morning Locations: the Connaigre, Burin, and Avalon peninsulas. Time span: through this evening. Remarks: Strong westerly winds accompanying the snow squalls will produce poor visibilities in blowing snow. Conditions are expected to improve this near midnight. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and persistent visibility near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Further snowfall amounts: generally 5 to 10 cm except locally 25 cm or more in snow squalls. Maximum wind gusts: westerly 80 to 100 km/h except locally as high as 110 km/h from the Port au Port Peninsula south to Port aux Basques tonight until Tuesday morning. Locations: the west coast of Newfoundland, Deer Lake, and the Humber Valley. Time span: continuing until Tuesday evening. Remarks: Intense snow squalls, in conjunction with very strong westerly winds, will continue until Tuesday evening. Visibility will be frequently reduced to near zero to give blizzard like conditions in blowing snow. Little improvement is expected until winds begin to ease on Tuesday evening. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Warning of potential breaking sea conditions and overwash issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - Quebec Area on 2019-12-16. Higher than normal water levels and large waves are expected near the coast today. An intense low pressure system will produce strong to high winds over the areas listed below. The combination of these winds and the current run of high amplitude tides could produce breaking sea conditions along the coast near the following localities, on the dates and at the times specified (Eastern Standard Time). Rimouski - Mont-Joli: 2019-12-16, from 3 PM to 7 PM. Matane: 2019-12-16, from 3 PM to 7 PM. ### High waves combined with the surge may cause damage along the coast. Coastal erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T02:04:38-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A warm front and associated low pressure centre will approach the north coast tonight. Ahead of the front, snow will intensify this evening for inland areas of the north coast. As the warm air moves onto the coast, snow will change to freezing rain at Kitimat and spread toward Terrace. Overnight, Kitimat will likely change to rain while freezing rain persists inland. At Stewart, precipitation is expected to remain as snow tonight and Tuesday morning with total snowfall amounts of 25 to 35 cm. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

Conditions are expected to improve overnight tonight as winds begin to ease. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. 10 to 15 cm of snow will fall on Tuesday as a low pressure system crosses northern BC. Heavy snow will begin early Tuesday morning and ease by late afternoon. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and visibility frequently near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Additional snowfall: locally 10 to 15 cm in snow squalls. Maximum wind gusts: westerly 80 km/h except up to 100 km/h along the coast until Tuesday morning. Locations: Burgeo and the Burgeo Highway. Time span: continuing until Tuesday morning. Remarks: Visibilities are expected to be near zero in snow squalls and blowing snow. Snow squalls are expected to continue to produce blizzard conditions inland along the Burgeo highway tonight. Conditions will improve along the coast this evening. Highway conditions will improve Tuesday morning. ### Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blizzard warnings are issued when widespread reduced visibilities of 400 metres or less are expected for at least 4 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-17T11:29:28-00:00

Area: Burgeo - Ramea

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls from Lake Superior continue this evening and into Tuesday. Snow squalls from Lake Superior moving through the region are expected to bring additional amounts of up to 10 cm by morning. Snow at times heavy may make travel hazardous and visibilities reduced. Consider postponing non-essential travel until conditions improve. The snow squalls are expected to drift to the south of the region tomorrow afternoon and then weaken by Tuesday evening. ### Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T15:53:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-16T23:54:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1354646068.2019
Area: Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. A Pacific frontal system will approach the BC coast tonight. The front will stall over northern Vancouver Island on Tuesday before shifting southward on Wednesday. This storm is forecast to bring widespread heavy rainfall to the west coast of Vancouver Island. For Tofino and communities further north such as Zeballos and Tahsis, heavy rain is expected for Tuesday and Tuesday night. As the front begins to move southward early Wednesday, heavy rain will start to impact communities south of Tofino. Total rainfall amounts in the range of 100 to 150 mm can be expected for this event. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-17T15:34:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-16T23:35:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3617340117.2019
Area: West Vancouver Island

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this evening. Snow squalls from Lake Superior continue to move through the region this evening. Additional snowfall amounts of 5 cm are possible by tonight. Snow at times heavy will make travel hazardous and visibilities reduced. Consider postponing non-essential travel until conditions improve. The snow squalls are expected to move out of the region tonight before returning tomorrow morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
